title-group.article-title: Quantitative high-resolution winter (JJA) precipitation reconstruction from varved sediments of Lago Plomo 47°S, Patagonian Andes, ad 1530–2002

author-notes.corresp: Julie Elbert, University of Bern, Oeschger Centre & Institute of Geography, Erlachstrasse 9a T3, 3012 Bern, Switzerland. Email: julie.elbert@giub.unibe.ch

abstract.p: High-resolution climate reconstructions from a range of natural archives across the world are fundamental to place current climate change into perspective. Paleoclimate records for the Southern Hemisphere are scarce and only a few quantitative high-resolution reconstructions exist for the past millennium. We present a record of annually laminated sediments of Lago Plomo (46°59′S, 72°52′W,203 m a.s.l.) located east of the Northern Patagonian Ice Field (NPI). Radiometric dating (210Pb, 137Cs, 14C AMS) is consistent with counts of millimetre-scale laminae, confirming the annual nature of the laminae couplets with a light summer and a dark winter layer. The varves were analyzed for thickness, mass accumulation rate (MAR), scanning x-ray fluorescence (XRF) and scanning reflectance spectroscopy in the visible range (VIS-RS). MAR data were calibrated against austral winter (JJA) precipitation data (CRU TS 3.0) for the period ad 1930–2002 (r = 0.67, p(aut) < 0.05). Using a linear inverse regression model we reconstructed winter precipitation for Lago Plomo back to ad 1530. The root mean squared error of prediction (RMSEP) is small (13.3 mm/month; 12% of the average precipitation) compared with the pronounced decadal and multidecadal variability, suggesting that most of the reconstructed variability is significant. Wetter phases (reference ad 1930–2002) were observed around ad 1600, ad 1630–1690 and ad 1780–1850, and a prolonged drier period ad 1690–1780 with a multidecadal minimum centered on ad 1770. The spatial correlation for South America suggests that the JJA precipitation record from Lago Plomo is representative for large areas in the southwest between c. 41°S and 51°S.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In order to place recent climatic changes into the long-term perspective, regional expressions of forced and unforced natural variability must be understood and discriminated from anthropogenic sources of climate change. Therefore, investigating past regional, hemispheric and global climatic changes is crucial for understanding present and future climate change, assessing the underlying dynamics and teleconnections, and to reduce uncertainties in future projections (Hegerl et al., 2006).

South America is of particular interest because it is the only large land mass that extends through the main area of the modern Southern Hemisphere westerly wind belt at 40–55°S and, therefore, plays a crucial role for paleoclimate reconstruction in the Southern Hemisphere (e.g. Garreaud et al., 2009). The precipitation regime in southern South America is very variable both in space and time because of the topography of the Andes and changes in the strength and latitudinal position of the southern Westerlies (Garreaud et al., 2009). Precipitation is also influenced by the Southern Annular Mode (SAM) and El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO).

Whereas much progress has been made in the development of paleoclimate records in Europe and North America, the Southern Hemisphere still lacks high-quality data sets with adequate temporal and spatial distribution (Mann et al., 2008; Villalba et al., 2009), and information about temperature and precipitation for specific seasons of the year is heterogeneous. In the most recent comprehensive multiproxy and multisite summer temperature reconstruction for southern South America for the last millennium, Neukom et al. (2010b) only found five summer temperature records of adequate quality extending back beyond ad 1650. Most of these data sets are from tree ring studies, corals or ice cores and only one from lake sediments (von Gunten et al., 2009a). For precipitation, the data base is even worse (Neukom et al., 2010a): the comprehensive reconstruction for South America does not reach further back than ad 1498 for summer precipitation and ad 1590 for winter precipitation.

At the regional level, distinct differences exist between the northern (40–47°S) and southern (47–55°S) Patagonian climates. This is shown by tree-ring derived temperature reconstructions in both areas (Villalba et al., 2003): while some features (e.g. a strong warming trend between ad 1850 and 1920) were found in both areas, the regional expressions of decadal and multidecadal variability were mostly out of phase between northern and southern Patagonia for the past 250 years. These opposite temperature trends are particularly striking in the past 50 years when northern Patagonia experienced a strong cooling and southern Patagonia a strong warming (Falvey and Garreaud, 2009).

Paleoclimate information in the south (Lago Guanaco 51°S; Moy et al., 2009) suggests a gradual increase in the westerly flow and decreasing temperatures culminating during the ‘Little Ice Age’ (LIA, c. ad 1550–1900). Interestingly, Laguna Las Vizcachas (50°42′S) further to the east shows similar cool conditions between c. ad 1450–1650 but afterwards relatively warm and moist conditions until c. ad 1750 (Fey et al., 2009). High lake levels and cool conditions persisted in the Pali Aike Volcanic Field (52°S, East Patagonian Steppe) throughout the LIA, particularly between ad 1670 and 1890 (Haberzettl et al., 2005). However, the modern wind/precipitation relationship suggests that western and eastern Patagonia should show opposite humidity responses to enhanced westerly flow (wetter in the west, drier in the east; Moy et al., 2009), which is only partly reflected in the regional records.

Further north of our study site, high resolution marine sediment cores also suggest northward displacement of the westerlies, wetter conditions and cooler sea surface temperatures (SST) between ad 1550 and 1750 followed by rapid warming and drying between ad 1750 and 1850 (Lamy et al., 2002). The precise ages of these changes (calibrated 14C ages) are, however poorly constrained (e.g. one 14C date per 1000 years). The most detailed study is the quantitative annually resolved autumn/winter recipitation reconstruction from varved Lago Puyehue (41°S) for the past 600 years (Boës and Fagel, 2008). This record is highly accurate in its chronology and reveals strong multidecadal to centennial precipitation variability. Tree ring series from northern Patagonia show pronounced decadal variability in precipitation, stream flow and temperature fluctuating around a mean value, whereby a low-frequency structure as found in the sediment records during the LIA is hardly visible (Boninsegna et al., 2009).

The only paleoclimate record close to our study site comes from Glaciar Soler, an outlet glacier of the Northern Patagonian Ice Field (NPI) in the catchment of Lago Plomo. 14C dated advances were reported for the mid-fourteenth century and the beginning of the eighteenth century (Glasser et al., 2002), followed by several minor advances until ad 1950. Generally, glaciers in northern Patagonia showed the LIA maximum in the nineteenth century, while glaciers in southern Patagonia were largest in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries (Masiokas et al., 2009).

We present an annually resolved quantitative calibrated and validated austral winter precipitation reconstruction from lake sediments in the Patagonian Andes at 47°S back to ad 1530. This area is located in the climatic transition zone between southern (47°S–55°S) and northern (c. 37°S–47°S) Patagonia (Boninsegna et al., 2009; Garreaud et al., 2009). Our record is based on varved (annually laminated) sediments from proglacial Lago Plomo. Such sediments are rare for South America (e.g. Ariztegui et al., 2007).

This paper starts with a description of the lake and the catchment followed by a detailed microstratigraphic characterization of the sediment laminae. We then compare laminae counts with radionuclide activity profiles to establish (i) an independent chronology supporting the annual nature of the laminae couplets and (ii) the varve chronology. Mass Accumulation Rates (MAR) were calibrated to austral winter precipitation, validated, and extended back to ad 1530. Finally, our reconstruction is compared with regional paleoclimate records.

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: Lago Plomo (46°59′S, 72°52′W, 203 m a.s.l.) is a proglacial, polymictic, oligotrophic, deep (> 200 m) exorheic lake located on the eastern side of the NPI. It is partly dammed by a Lateglacial moraine and drains through an isthmus to Lago Bertrand.

The catchment (Figure 1a) extends with deep valleys and very steep slopes to the glaciers and snowfields of the NPI in the west and the Cordon Contreras in the north; peaks range up to c. 2000 m. Bedrock in the catchment is mostly composed of Devonian carboniferous sandstone and phyllite, and Jurassic quartzous diorite, granodiorite, granite and tonalite with biotite, pyroxene and hornblende (SERNAGEOMIN, 2003). Snow and ice meltwater from the NPI, mainly from the Soler glacier and other smaller outlet glaciers drain into Lago Plomo and transport fluvioglacial sediments into the lake. Glasser et al. (2009) reported that the Soler glacier (50 km2, visited in ad 2000) is a land-terminating glacier, but currently recedes into a shallow moraine-dammed proglacial lake. The glacier formed a low, cross-valley proglacial moraine, ice scoured bedrock and extensive sandar deposits on the major ice discharge route. These glaciofluvial outwash plains are composed of rounded sandy gravel or sand present at the valley floor (Glasser et al., 2009). The course of the river Soler is very variable, which is shown by several old courses on the outwash plain. Small rivers on the side slopes close to our coring site have smaller watersheds and no glaciers in their catchment and therefore contribute less to the sediment transport into the lake. The water of the lake contains a lot of suspended material which leads to very limited light transparency (Secchi-disc depth = 0.5 m). The water column did not show temperature stratification during summer (January 2009). The degree of mineralization is extremely low (electric conductivity 26.7 µS/cm), the pH is neutral (7.1) and phosphate concentrations were below detection limit.

caption.p: (a) Geographical setting of the study area (modified from Glasser et al., 2009). (b) Close-up view of coring site area and winter precipitation teleconnections between our study site and the rest of South America. The contour map shows the bathymetry (m water depth) of the confluent area of Lago Plomo and Lago Bertrand. The coring sites of PLO-09-4 and PLO-09-5 at 29 m water depth are marked with an asterisk. Inset: Winter precipitation (JJA) Pearson correlation map between study site (white rectangle) and South America (upper map) and the corresponding P-values (values < 0.05 in red; lower map)

sec.p: Figure 1b shows the coring site (46°58.934′S/72°51.799′W, 29 m water depth) and the bathymetry. The coring site was 300 m off the shore in the distal part of the lake on a small flat area.

Today, a temperate climate characterizes the area and is dominated by the westerly winds and precipitation. The CRU TS 3.0 data set (Mitchell and Jones, 2005) shows average annual temperatures for Lago Plomo of 5–6°C and c. 990 mm annual precipitation. The closest climate stations are Puerto Aysen, Chile Chico, Coyhaique and Balmaceda, but the records are very short and discontinuous, and the spatial precipitation gradients are very steep. The Andes play a major role in rainfall distribution: orographic precipitation leads to a local maximum (6000–7000 mm) on the windward side (Garreaud et al., 2009), decreases to about 1000 mm on the eastern slopes of the Andes, and to as little as 300 mm at Chile Chico on the border with Argentina. The NPI is dependent on the vigorous mid-latitude weather systems, which bring high rainfall; ablation rates are high, mass balance gradients steep and ice flow velocities high (Matsuoka and Naruse, 1999; Michel and Rignot, 1999; Rott et al., 1998). Therefore glacier fluctuations are a response to changing circulation patterns including both equatorward and poleward shifts in the moisture-bearing southern Westerlies (Glasser et al., 2002). In this area the Westerlies are strongest during austral summer peaking between 45° and 55°S. During winter, low level Westerlies expand equatorward but weaken (particularly at ~50°S), while the jet stream moves to lower latitudes (Garreaud et al., 2009). In the western part of Patagonia, the strength of the Westerlies and precipitation are positively correlated. This relationship disappears or becomes negative in the eastern part of Patagonia where Atlantic moisture sources increase.

The correlation field analysis (Figure 1 inset, CRU TS 3.0, Mitchell and Jones, 2005, 47.0°S 72.5°W, ad 1930–2000) shows that Austral winter precipitation at Lago Plomo is positively correlated with winter precipitation in southern Chile and southwestern Argentina (41–51°S), showing the regional influence of the southern Westerlies.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: In January 2009 two parallel sediment cores of 1.2 and 0.86 m length (PLO-09-4 and PLO-09-5, respectively) were retrieved from the distal part of Lago Plomo at a water depth of 29 m (Figure 1b). We used an UWITEC gravity corer. The cores were sealed and stored under dark and cool (4°C) conditions prior to analysis. Radiometric dating, non-destructive reflectance spectrometry (VIS-RS) and varve counts were performed on PLO-09-5 while scanning x-ray fluorescence (XRF), varve counts, VIS-RS, MAR and thin sections were made on PLO-09-4. The data from the shorter core (PLO-09-5) were stratigraphically correlated varve by varve to the master core PLO-09-4.

Immediately after opening, the cores were analyzed with scanning (2 mm resolution) VIS-RS (visible spectrum: 380–730 nm; spectral resolution 10 nm) using a Gretag Mcbeth Spectrolino (Rein and Sirocko, 2002; Trachsel et al., 2010). The characteristic patterns and absorption bands of the reflectance spectra provide information about organic compounds (mainly photopigments; Rein and Sirocko, 2002; von Gunten et al., 2009a) and the concentration and composition of lithic matter (Rein et al., 2005; Trachsel et al., 2010). Here we use two established proxies: (i) clastic sediments show a systematic increase in reflectance between 570 nm and 630 nm wavelength (i.e. the slope between 570 and 630 nm; R570/R630), which is attributed to illite, chlorite and biotite, and thus serves as a proxy for the concentration of the lithogenic fraction in the sediments (Rein and Sirocko, 2002; Trachsel et al., 2010); (ii) total brightness as calculated from the average reflectance of the 36 channels (Rein et al., 2005) is used as a proxy indicating the relative proportions of the light summer layer to the dark winter layer in the varves.

The AVAATECH XRF Core Scanner ‘LisbETH’ of the Geological Institute ETH Zurich provided information about the elemental composition of the sediments at a 0.2 mm measuring resolution. Al, Si, P, S, Cl, K, Ca, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe were measured at a tube voltage of 10 kV. The split sediment core surface was covered with a 4 µm thick Ultralene SPEX CertiPrep-foil to avoid contamination and desiccation of the sediment.

The nature of the laminations was investigated and the laminae counts performed under a light microscope and an environmental Scanning Electron Microscope LEO (Carl Zeiss) EVO 40XVP-BU on epoxy resin embedded (Lotter and Lemcke, 1999) and polished (6 µm) sediment blocks of 18 cm length. Four sediment sequences (6.7–8 cm; 10.8–12.1 cm; 99–100.3 cm; 102.5–103.8 cm sediment depth of PLO-09-4) were scanned with a µ-XRF EAGLE III XRF, whereby the spatial arrangement of Al, Br, Mn, Ti, Si, Ca and Fe was mapped at ~100 µm resolution under vacuum conditions. This provided information on the elemental (and thus mineralogical) composition of the dark and the light laminae. The mineralogical composition of bulk sediments was determined with quantitative x-ray diffraction (XRD).

Laminae were counted by two people, five times each, along different lines on the resin-embedded sediment blocks using the software package Image J. Varve thickness measurements followed the same procedure.

The core PLO-09-5 was sampled at 0.5 cm intervals for 210Pb and 137Cs activity and water content measurements. Gamma ray counts of 210Pb (46.5 keV) and 137Cs (662 keV) were collected for more than 20 h using Canberra low background, well HPGe-detectors at EAWAG Duebendorf. 226Ra was determined by measuring the activity of 214Pb (352keV) and 214Bi (609keV) (in radioactive equilibrium). Unsupported 210Pb was calculated with the level-by-level method from the 226Ra activity (Appleby, 2001). The measurement at 11.84 cm was not used for 210Pb age modeling because of anomalously low activity values. In order to convert 210Pb activity profiles into ages, we used three different numerical model types, the Constant Initial Concentration (CIC), Constant Rate of Supply (CRS, Appleby, 2001) and the Sediment Isotope Tomography (SIT) model (Carroll et al., 1999). The CIC model displayed several age inversions and was not used.
137Cs measurements were used as an independent time marker to constrain the 210Pb age models. 137Cs fallout in this area peaked in ad 1963 (The Environmental Measurements Laboratory, 2008).

A small fragment of wood buried in the sediments of core PLO-09-5 was AMS radiocarbon dated at the Poznan Radiocarbon Laboratory, Poland, and calibrated using the ShCal04 Southern Hemisphere Calibration curve (McCormac et al., 2004).

We used the 137Cs-constrained 210Pb age models and the radiocarbon measurement to (i) corroborate the annual nature of the lamina couplets and (ii) verify the varve counting chronologies. The varve chronology with the smallest offset to the most plausible 210Pb chronology (constrained SIT and constrained CRS) was used to convert varve thickness measurements into annual MAR after Niessen et al. (1992):

where s is average sedimentation rates between two dated points in cored sediments (varve thickness), ρs is dry density of sediments (2.45 g/cm3), ρw is pore-water density (1.0 g/cm3), w is water content (%).

Subsequently the time series of annual MAR was detrended using locally weighted regression (loess, span = 0.85) to remove multicentury trends which might be related to non-climatic causes or indirect effects such as long-term ecosystem evolution in the catchment (e.g. vegetation dynamics and glacier length variations). Locally weighted regression estimates a regression surface to data through a multivariate smoothing procedure. The dependent variable is smoothed as a function of the independent variables in a moving form (Cleveland and Devlin, 1988).

As it is not a-priori known which climate variable and season is best predicted by our proxies measured, we prepared a correlation matrix and compared MAR with the seasonal and annual temperature and precipitation data of the CRU TS 3.0 data set (Mitchell and Jones, 2005; grid cell 46.5–47.0°S and 72.5–73.0°W). Local meteorological data are not available. As we will show in the section below, MAR data best predict winter (June–August, JJA) precipitation. We used the Pearson’s product moment correlation coefficient r2 and corrected the p-values for autocorrelation (p(aut), Dawdy and Matalas, 1964).

The CRU TS precipitation data perform well in this area and are highly correlated with the nearest long regional weather station in Puerto Aysen (r = 0.91, p (aut) < 0.001, 1931–1992). Data from 1992 onwards are missing. Before ad 1930, the quality of the reanalysis data is reduced because of a strong decline in the number of stations available (e.g. Garreaud et al., 2009; Neukom et al., 2010a). Therefore, we select the calibration period starting from ad 1930. As varve counting in the soft topmost sediments is ambiguous, we end the calibration period in the year ad 2002 (see below).

For the calibration, we used raw and five-years triangular filtered MAR data. The spread of the filter was selected according to the varve counting uncertainties in the calibration period (e.g. Koining et al., 2002). The climate inference model was calculated with linear inverse regression. Split period validation was performed using a calibration (ad 1967–2002) and validation (ad 1930–1966) period. We calculated the reduction of error (RE) and the coefficient of efficiency (CE) after Cook et al. (1994). Leave-one-out cross-validation (jack knifing) was carried out on the entire calibration period (ad 1930–2002) to calculate RMSEP. Finally, winter precipitation was reconstructed back to ad 1530.

sec.title: Sediment classification and microfacies analysis
sec.p: The sediments of Lago Plomo consist of light gray (Munsell color: gley 1–4/10GY) silty clay (median 6.0 µm) with very low concentrations of organic matter (TOC < 1%). No diatoms or algae are present in the sediment and microscopic investigation of the resin embedded blocks showed very few terrestrial microfossils, namely larvae, remains of insects and small fragments of wood. The lithogenic fraction is composed of quartz (10–12%), orthoclase (c. 10%), plagioclase (38–45%) and clay minerals (c. 40%, not specified). The composition is very homogenous throughout the 120 cm long core.

Both cores show rhythmically laminated sediments that alternate between a light silty and a dark clay-rich millimetre-scale layer. The contacts between the silty and overlying clay-rich laminae are continuous. In contrast, the boundaries between clay-rich and overlying silty laminae are sharp. Each couplet with a silty and its overlying clay-rich layer represents a fining upward sequence as shown in Figure 2. These changes in particle size and colour correlate well with variations in elemental composition (Figure 2b): the silty laminae contain higher concentrations of Fe whereas the clay laminae showed higher Ca and Si values.

(b) Picture and elemental maps derived from XRF measurements of resin embedded sediment of PLO-09-4 at core depth 102.5–103.8 cm. The elemental maps show Fe/Si and Fe/Ca ratios, respectively. Light layers in the photography have higher relative Iron contents and darker layers are enriched in silicium and calcium

sec.title: Chronology
sec.p: Figure 3a shows the226Ra, 210Pb and 137Cs activity profiles and the age–depth model as calculated with the constrained and unconstrained CRS and SIT models. 137Cs activity peaks at a core depth of 8.5 cm and is used as a time-marker to constrain the CRS and SIT age models to ad 1963 (Figure 3b).

caption.p: (a) Activity measurements for 210Pb, 226Ra and 137Cs. (b) Age–depth model (CRS, SIT and varve counting) for the upper 25 cm of PLO-09-4A. For clarity error bars are only shown for the constrained models. (c) Varve counting for whole core and radiocarbon measurement

sec.p: The varve counting error amounts to ± 2.4 years from the top of the core to the depth of the 137Cs peak (ad 1963) and increases towards the bottom of the core (ad 1530) cumulatively to ± 18.5 varve years (c. 4%; Figure 3c). Figure 3b also shows a systematic offset of 4–6 varve years between the constrained 210Pb ages and the varve counts. The 210Pb profiles suggest that the ‘missing varves’ were lost in the top 1–2 cm of the core. This may be due to the very soft surface sediments and disturbance of the sediment–water interface during coring. Below 2 cm sediment depth, the varve counting and radiometric chronologies are consistent and go nicely in parallel. Thus for the final chronology, we fitted the varve chronology of the sediments below c. 1 cm sediment depth through the radiometric chronology (Figure 3b; parallel shift of 6 years) and do not use the years 2003–2008 for calibration. Also, the radiocarbon age of the wood fragment at 41 cm sediment depth (140 ± 30 14C yr BP, POZ-31863, calibrated midpoint ad 1840, ± 1σ range ad 1698–1945) fits with the varve counts (Figure 3c). The uncertainty range of calibrated 14C ages is, however, large in this period of time.

The overall varve count chronology is consistent with the radiometric chronology (210Pb, 137Cs, 14C). Therefore we interpret the lamina couplets as clastic varves, whereby one light layer and one dark layer represent sedimentation during one year. We interpret the light silty layer as deposition during the season when water inflows and undercurrents in the lake are very active, the suspended sediment load and the density of the lake water is high, and relatively coarse grains may be transported to the distal parts of the lake. Clay size sediments remain largely in suspension and are exported to Lago Bertrand. This is typical for the snow and ice melt season in spring and summer. In contrast, the dark clay-rich layer would be deposited in winter, when less kinetic energy is available (no snowmelt, weak undercurrents and weak winds) and conditions are calm.
The sedimentation rate appears relatively constant throughout the core.

sec.title: Sediment proxies
sec.p: Figure 4 summarizes the results of the XRF scans for the selected elements Fe, Ca and Si along with water content measurements, the two VIS-RS proxies (R570/R630 and Brightness), MAR and varve thickness measurements. Total Fe shows relatively high values. A sharp drop towards the top of the core and lower values for the upper 5 cm were observed. Also Ca and Si show a decreasing trend towards the upper part of the core which goes along with increasing water content. The proxy R570/R630 (VIS-RS), indicative of illite, biotite, chlorite concentrations, is also negatively correlated with water content but is very stable in the lower part of the core. The sediments show relatively high reflection (brightness) at the bottom of the core and at around 40 cm core depth (around ad 1810), low values around 70 cm core depth (around ad 1690), and a decrease towards the top of the core. MAR ranges between 0.1 and 0.4 g/cm2 per yr. Both brightness and MAR show a fairly similar pattern suggesting that the variability in MAR is largely dominated by variability in the thickness of the light summer layer: relatively thick summer layers would increase the brightness of the sediments as measured by VIS-RS. Varve thickness ranges between 1 and 4 mm and shows slightly higher values at the bottom part of the core.

caption.p: XRF scan data for Fe, Ca, and Si (in cps), water content (%), R570/R630 and average reflection brightness (%) derived from VIS-RS, mass accumulation rate MAR (mg/cm2 per yr) and varve thickness (mm) of Lago Plomo (core PLO-09-4)

sec.title: Calibration and precipitation reconstruction
sec.p: The correlation matrix (MAR correlated with seasonal, annual precipitation and temperature data; matrix table and data not shown) revealed that the best calibration for our data set is obtained from MAR as a predictor for JJA precipitation. Figure 5 shows the meteorological and the MAR data (annual and 5-years triangular filtered, loess detrended with span = 0.85) that were used for the calibration interval ad 1930–2002. Annual MAR data show a highly significant correlation (r = 0.42, p(aut) < 0.0005) with Austral winter (JJA) precipitation. Since the varve ages are probabilistic, we accounted for varve counting uncertainties and smoothed the annual MAR data and the JJA precipitation with a 5-year triangular filter. This reveals a better correlation but a loss in the significance level due to increasing autocorrelation of the time series and a loss of degrees of freedom (r = 0.67, p(aut) = 0.049).

caption.p: Annual and 5-year triangular filtered precipitation data (mm/month) from CRU TS3, and annual and 5-year triangular filtered mass accumulation rate MAR (mg/cm2 per yr; loess detrended with span = 0.85) for the calibration period ad 1930–2002

sec.p: Calibration and validation using split periods (calibration period ad 1967–2002; verification period ad 1930–1966) shows a RE of 0.47, a CE of 0.17, and a RMSE of 15.8 mm/month. Leave-one-out cross-validation using the entire calibration period (ad 1930–2002) results in a RMSEP of 13.25 mm/month, which is 12% of the average precipitation and 59% of the average amplitude of interannual variability of the reconstruction (i.e. standard deviation).

Using the calibration model we reconstructed Austral winter precipitation for Lago Plomo back to ad 1530 (Figure 6a). With a few exceptions for both dry and humid extremes, the reconstructed precipitation ranges within the amplitude covered during the calibration period. The record indicates lower winter precipitation (with regard to the twentieth century) for the second half of the sixteenth century followed by two decades with higher precipitation ad 1590–1610. Precipitation falls below the twentieth-century mean ad 1610–1630 while the second half of the seventeenth century was very humid. The eighteenth century experiences greater variability and generally very dry conditions. The end of the eighteenth century is characterized by a sharp rise in precipitation above average ad 1780–1850, followed by drying until the end of the nineteenth century. Decadal and multidecadal variability is pronounced during the entire record.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In order to assess the quality of the austral winter precipitation reconstruction here, a number of related issues are fundamental. Most critical is the question whether or not the laminae couplets are annual deposits as this determined the chronology. This in turn is fundamental for developing the proxy–climate calibration and the temporal accuracy of the paleoclimate reconstruction. Furthermore, the robustness of the calibration method needs to be evaluated and a mechanistic explanation is required to corroborate the statistical relationship between MAR and JJA precipitation. Finally, we need to synthesize a regional paleoclimate picture that is dynamically consistent and reflects existing teleconnection patterns.

sec.title: Are the laminae seasonal and how good is the chronology?
sec.p: Two independent lines of argument support our interpretation that the laminae couplets are annual deposits.

From the sedimentological and microstratigraphic point of view, the laminae of Lago Plomo are very similar to the clastic varves that have been identified in Laguna Frias, which is located in a comparable setting on the east side of the Andes: Ariztegui et al. (2007) found light and dark layers, and suggested that the light silty material would be deposited during spring and summer snowmelt whereas the darker clay material would be deposited in winter under calmer conditions. In Laguna Frias the material is partly washed out by rainfall from the catchment and partly transported by fluvio-glacial processes into the lake. Glaciers produce fine sediment material by abrasion of the bedrock, which is carried as suspension load by meltwater during spring and summer and deposited in the lake. The erosion rate is dependent on the glacier size and thickness and therefore indirectly controlled by climate (summer temperature and winter precipitation). Therefore climatic changes can be archived in proglacial lake sediments, as variations in the accumulated amount of the silt- and clay-sized mineral fraction in a proglacial lake (Leemann and Niessen, 1994). A limiting factor for sediment accumulation in winter is the strong seasonality of the meteorological parameters (higher precipitation and lower temperature) and that most of the catchment of Laguna Frias remains frozen (Ariztegui et al., 2007).

A similar process provides a mechanistic explanation for the relationship between MAR and winter precipitation in Lago Plomo: winter precipitation (snow) reaches the lake during snowmelt in spring and summer, when detrital sediments are conveyed by active undercurrents to the distal part of the lake and form the coarse and light summer layer of the varve couplet. It is expected that MAR of the summer layer also contains a summer precipitation and/or a temperature signal. However, this does not seem to be statistically significant but may contribute to the error of prediction in the calibration model.

In order to confirm the annual nature of the laminations it is important to compare the lamina counts with independent age determination such as 210Pb model age profiles, 137Cs markers and radiocarbon dating. We systematically tested different 210Pb age models (CIC, CRS and SIT) and found that the constrained CRS and SIT models produced very similar results. This was also found by von Gunten et al. (2009b) who tested the 210Pb age models on clastic sediments from two high-elevation glacial lakes in the Central Chilean Andes. The CIC model was rejected because of multiple age inversions. Overall, the constrained 210Pb chronologies are highly consistent with the varve counts during the calibration period. Additionally, the radiocarbon age mid-point of a small wood fragment is in line with varve counts around ad 1840 suggesting that the varve chronology is also robust on longer timescales. However, the age uncertainty (calibration range) of 14C dates in this time period is very large.

The varve counting was carried out repeatedly by different people in order to gain an estimation of the chronological uncertainty (± 18.5 varves cumulatively for the total core length). The uncertainty of the chronology and the probabilistic nature of the sediment ages during the calibration period (± 3.5 varves) determines the degree of Gaussian or triangular data filtering that is recommended for the proxy–climate calibration-in-time (Koining et al., 2002). However, the degree of smoothing marks the upper limit of the temporal resolution for the reconstruction, which is meaningful for palaeoclimate interpretations, enhances the correlation coefficient but also reduces the statistical significance of the correlation (predictor-predictand) because the time series get increasingly autocorrelated (Dawdy and Matalas, 1964).

A common problem for proxy–climate calibration and 210Pb dating is the disturbance of the soft sediment–water interface during coring. Disturbed, erroneously identified or missing varves may lead to wrong interpretations of the palaeoclimate signal. We found that varve counting and radiometric chronologies go nicely in parallel below 1–2 cm sediment depth whereas a few varves seem to be missing at the top. In Lago Plomo, varve identification in the top sediments is not unambiguous. Thus, we have systematically tested the match between the varve chronology and (i) the independent radiometric chronology and (ii) the results of the calibration statistics by varying the number of varves ‘lost’ in the top sediments. The best match appeared with a lag of minus six varves, when the varve chronology fits through the 210Pb chronology and the 137Cs marker, and the calibration statistics perform best.

sec.title: How good are the calibration and the reconstruction?
sec.p: Another important issue is to systematically evaluate the quality of the calibration with the meteorological data set. Since very few regional weather stations exist and records are often discontinuous, we have chosen the gridded precipitation data from the CRU TS 3.0 data set (Mitchell and Jones, 2005) to calibrate the MAR record. The gridded data perform well in this area and are highly correlated with the nearest reasonably long regional weather station in Puerto Aysen.

The length of the calibration period and the amplitude of variability represented during this time are most critical for the calibration-in-time approach. Although the calibration period is very short (77 years), it features a large range from dry (ad 1940–1955 and ad 1982–1997) to very humid conditions (ad 1955–1981), encompassing most of the variability comprised in the proxy data series during the last 480 years.

The MAR record is well dated and has been developed independently. It appears from Figure 5 that MAR data and meteorological data (5-years filtered) are sometimes offset by 1–2 years, which is likely due to varve counting errors. This offset is smaller than the varve counting uncertainty and can be adjusted for. The mineralogical composition, color and microstratigraphy of the sediments remain the same throughout the entire core, which allows us to extrapolate the calibration model from the recent sediments back in time.

The proxy data were loess detrended to eliminate possible low-frequency non-climate effects on the sedimentation rate. The span was chosen to ensure the full interannual to multidecadal variability of the calibration period was retained, but (multi)centennial effects such as long-term glacier length variations, vegetation dynamics or soil formation were eliminated.

To reconstruct precipitation we tested linear inverse regression, linear inverse prediction and scaling as statistical methods. Linear inverse regression, the most commonly used method revealed the best results (i.e. smallest RMSEP). The RMSEP of 13.3 mm/month is very small compared with the amplitude of the decadal variability, which means that most of the changes observed are significant.

sec.title: How well does the reconstruction fit with the regional paleoclimate history (North and South Patagonia)?
sec.p: Our record shows very humid phases around ad 1600, 1640–1690 and around ad 1780–1850; dry periods occurred generally in the eighteenth century and the second half of the nineteenth century through to the present.

Since Lago Plomo is located in the transition zone between north and south Patagonia we may expect changing influences from both the north and the south. At least temperature-wise over the past 400 years, both areas at times show a coherent pattern (Villalba et al., 2003). The spatial distribution of rainfall makes regional comparisons more difficult.

The paleoclimate archive closest to our study site is Glaciar Soler. 14C and tree ring dated maximum advances prior to ad 1720 and prior to ad 1850 (minimum ages; Masiokas et al., 2009) are consistent with humid phases and enhanced MAR in the late seventeenth century and the beginning of the nineteenth century, taking into account a response-lag of the glacier in the order of two to three decades and that glaciers in this area respond predominantly to humidity changes (Glasser et al., 2002).

More difficult is the comparison with marine SST and humidity records off the Chilean coast at 41°S (Lamy et al., 2002) and lake sediment/vegetation records from Laguna Las Vizcachas and Lago Guanaco at 51°S (Fey et al., 2009; Moreno et al., 2009; Moy et al., 2009). The main limitations are (i) the poor dating control (typically one 14C date per 500 or 1000 years, four in Laguna Las Vizcachas) and (ii) the presence of mixed signals (wind, precipitation, temperature and evaporation) in the sediment proxies. Judging from the data, it remains inconclusive whether the decadal-scale precipitation variability as presented in our record is in or out of phase with the decadal-scale variability of the hydrological cycle and/or strength of the zonal wind as shown in the other regional records. However, the wet phase in the late seventeenth century in west Patagonia (Lago Plomo, Laguna Las Vizcachas, marine proxies from GeoB-3313-1 at 41°S and to some extent at Lago Guanaco at 51°S) concurrent with the drying in east Patagonia (Haberzettl et al., 2005) appears regionally significant and dynamically consistent. In contrast, the beginning of the eighteenth century (1690–1780) appears dry in this region (Lago Plomo, Laguna Las Vizcachas) whereas east Patagonia (Laguna Potrok Aike) suggests enhanced fluvial input, which is in line with teleconnection patterns.

Surprising is the consistency of our record with the only existing highly resolved, well dated and quantitative winter precipitation reconstruction from Lago Puyehue 41°S (Figure 6b; Boës and Fagel, 2008). The quality and resolution of both records allows for a comparison of decadal-scale winter precipitation variability. As shown by the spatial correlation patterns (Figure 1 inset), the precipitation variability is correlated at Lago Plomo and Lago Puyehue, suggesting that both independent records provide a robust regional record. The authors report higher winter precipitation for the periods ad 1630–1730 and ad 1780–1820, which coincides with wet phases in our record (ad 1640–1690, ad1780–1850). Drier conditions at Lago Puyehue are reported for ad 1730–1780 and ad 1820–1920 and decreasing precipitation for ad 1950–2000. Dry phases at Lago Plomo occurred in the eighteenth century and the second half of the nineteenth century and from ad 1950 to the present.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The laminated sediments of Lago Plomo provide a quantitative high-resolution reconstruction of interannual to multidecadal winter precipitation variability for western Patagonia. This record is based on MAR and extends back to ad 1530 with high chronological accuracy. Independent 210Pb and 137Cs profiles and 14C AMS data confirmed the varve counts and thus the annual nature of the laminae. The varves have been counted repeatedly and counting uncertainty has been assessed to c. ± 4%.

The quantitative statistical relationship (calibration) between MAR and JJA precipitation is explained with a well-established mechanistic model: the light coarse-grained layer of the laminae couplet is formed during snowmelt in spring and summer, when large amounts of suspended sediments are transported in active undercurrents to the distal parts of the lake. In contrast, the clay-rich dark layer of the couplet is formed during winter under calm conditions. We conclude that (i) the laminae couplets are annual deposits and provide a highly accurate chronology with annual resolution, and that (ii) the varve formation process and the proxy to predict JJA precipitation (MAR) is understood and plausible.

The calibration-in-time has been tested and cross-validated. The statistics of the model indicate MAR may be used to reconstruct JJA precipitation with a small error of prediction. Further more, the calibration period covers most of the reconstructed decadal-scale variability and trends, which shows the robustness of the reconstruction from a statistical point of view.

The presented reconstruction provides insight into subdecadal- to centennial-scale climate variability for the area of 47°S, thus filling a gap between North and South Patagonia. Our record suggests more humid phases (with reference to the twentieth century) around ad 1600, in the late seventeenth and first half of the nineteenth century, and a prolonged drier period in the eighteenth century (ad 1690–1780) with a multidecadal minimum centered on ad 1770. However, decadal-scale variability was pronounced throughout our record (i.e. since 1530). Our JJA precipitation reconstruction compares well (even at the decadal scale) with a quantitative autumn/winter precipitation reconstruction from varved Lago Puyehue (41°S), which is consistent with spatial correlation patterns of the modern climate. Our record is also consistent with regional glacier length fluctuations, marine sediments off the Chilean coast (41°S) and lake sediment records in western and eastern Patagonia (51°S). These records are, however, relatively poorly constrained in their chronology and often contain mixed climatic signals. The overall comparison shows that our JJA precipitation record is robust and can be used to extend the comprehensive spatially explicit multiproxy and multisite reconstructions that are currently limited to ad 1750 (Neukom et al., 2010a).
